awd_titl_txt: Conference: An International Conference on Engineering  Synthetic Cells and Organelles
awd_abstract_narration:
The International Conference on Engineering Synthetic Cells and Organelles, SynCell 2023, will be held in Minneapolis, MN on May 22-24, 2023. The conference focuses on synthetic biology, establishes the state-of-the-art of synthetic cell technology, and identifies grand challenges and opportunities for future work in this field. It features world leaders in synthetic cell technology from premier US and international universities and national laboratories. The meeting addresses the mission of NSF, which has been increasingly committed to integrating the engineering sciences with the life sciences, encouraging research and development in multidisciplinary areas, educating the next generation of young scientists, and supporting cutting edge science to answer current and future challenges as well as making sure US-based scientists are globally engaged. 

Topics of the conference will focus on development of foundational technologies for creating synthetic cells. The conference will hold sessions on five topics over 2.5 days in a single-track format. The topics will be (1) cell-free translation systems; (2) education, outreach, ethics, and biosafety; (3) containers and cytoskeletons; (4) metabolism, gene replication, membrane synthesis, ribosome assembly; (5) synthetic cell applications in medicine and manufacturing; and (6) minimal cells as a living chassis. The conference proceedings, and companion white papers, will be published.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
Overview

SynCell 2023 was held at the McNamara Alumni center of the University of Minnesota – Minneapolis from May 22nd through May 24th. This annual academic conference hosts an array of international researchers, scientists, and other experts in the field of synthetic cells and synthetic biology. This is a hybrid (in-person and virtual) conference to accommodate the international community who cannot travel, or those with limited availability.

The SynCell community presented on many topics that range from advancements made in the bottom-up assembly of synthetic cell components, methods for promoting reproducibility, approaches to biosafety and biosecurity, and novel applications for synthetic cell technologies.

72 presentations (including keynotes, breakouts, and lightning talks) were given over the course of the three days covering ongoing research of 7 general categories. Applications, Beyond the Bench, Building Blocks, Cell-Free Translation Systems, Containers, Cytoskeleton, and Minimal Cell on Live Chassis. Monday saw a fantastic poster session of 55 poster presenters.

Working Groups

Three one-hour time slots were scheduled for attendees to divide into working groups and coordinate group projects. Groups included Ethics, Safety, Reproducibility, and Commercialization. Each group Is headed by a professional with a background and vested interest in the ongoing productivity of their group.

Working groups made great progress towards their collaborative efforts in the time available at the conference and are encouraged to continue their work together beyond the conference. Group leaders will engage with participants semi-regularly to keep group members active throughout the year until groups can re-assemble in person at SynCell 2024.

The Ethics group discussed issues faced in the field such as biosafety and the environment, biohacking, ownership, public value and global equity, and the philosophical and theoretical ethical concerns.

Outcomes: The group has drafted a white paper detailing the ethical complexities and approaches to synthetic cells research and applications to help in the development of a Synthetic Cell researcher statement on ethical issues such as a shared safety & alignment protocol.  

The Safety group organized to discuss how established safety and security protocol used by NASA for interplanetary protection can be applied to the future of synthetic cells.

Outcomes: Safety and Security group wrote and are ready to submit a paper in which biosafety is discussed using Nasa’s extraplanetary safety and security protocol. This will provide not only context for the greater public but also an appreciation and plan for future synthetic cell researchers.

The Reproducibility group, headed by professionals from the National Institute of Standards and Technology, began discussions on the struggle for consistent protocols and reproducibility. Reproducibility is not only a hurdle faced at bench scale research, but prevents synthetic cell technologies from gaining support from policy and regulation that is required for successful applications.

Outcomes: The Reproducibility group has two papers in preparation as a result of the conference. One an opinion discussion of action steps required by involved parties (funders, policy makers, and researchers) to create a reproducible and modular synthetic cell.  The second is a more detailed discussion of standardized protocols in ongoing research.

The Commercialization group aims to attract the attention of funding agencies by highlighting the many applications in which synthetic cell technologies out compete traditional methods across a myriad of applications.

Outcomes: The commercialization group is drafting papers on different categories of applications/commercial applications of synthetic cells. One such paper, “Environmental Applications of Synthetic Cells”, details how ongoing basic science utilizing synthetic cells contributes and guides environmental and sustainability objectives.

 


Last Modified: 04/22/2024
Modified by: Kate Adamala
